Its cognate ligand ( <extra_id_0> RANKL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) plays significant roles in the activation of dendritic cell function and osteoclast differentiation .

We demonstrate here the interaction of <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factors (TRAFs) 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> 6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> both in vitro and in cells .

text: Mapping of the structural requirements for TRAF / <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interaction revealed multiple TRAF binding sites clustered in two distinct domains in the <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cytoplasmic tail .

These TRAF binding domains were shown to be functionally important for the <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent induction of NF-kappaB and <extra_id_0> c-Jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> NH2-terminal kinase activities .

An NH2-terminal truncation mutant of <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibited <extra_id_0> RANKL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated NF-kappaB activation , but failed to affect constitutive signaling induced by receptor overexpression , revealing a selective role for <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in ligand - induced activation events .
